div.head: Summary
div.p: On their morning alms round, the Buddha and Maitreya meet Queen Kṣemavatī who is bedecked in all her royal jewelry. When the Buddha asks her about the source of such fine jewelry, referring to it metaphorically as fruit, Queen Kṣemavatī explains that her worldly position is the fruit of the tree of her previous good deeds. The remainder of the sūtra describes how one’s good actions can eventually lead to buddhahood, and it concludes with a prophecy for the queen’s future awakening.

div.head: Acknowledgements
div.p: Translated by the Subhashita Translation Group. The translation was produced by Benjamin Ewing who also wrote the introduction. Lowell Cook checked the translation against the Tibetan and edited the text.
The translation was completed under the patronage and supervision of 84000: Translating the Words of the Buddha.

The Prophecy of Kṣemavatī begins with the Buddha and his disciple, the bodhisattva Maitreya, walking through the city of Rājagṛha on their morning alms round. As they near King Bimbisāra’s palace, they are met by Queen Kṣemavatī, who is adorned with a dazzling display of royal jewelry. The Buddha asks the queen, in a seemingly playful way, for the name of the tree that produced the magnificent fruit that she is wearing. Queen Kṣemavatī continues the metaphor by describing her jewelry and her current station in life as the “fruit” borne by the “tree” of her past good deeds accumulated over lifetimes. This fruit and tree analogy is continued throughout the sūtra, with the Buddha describing his own station, that of complete awakening and all its excellent qualities, as also being the result of his past good deeds. This exchange emphasizes the main point of the text: that one’s current situation is the result of previous actions; thus, if we desire a good future we should persevere in meritorious behavior. The text concludes with Queen Kṣemavatī declaring that she will dedicate all her future good deeds toward reaching buddhahood and thereby be of benefit to all beings. The Buddha responds to this prayer by prophesying the queen’s eventual awakening to buddhahood.

Two times in this sūtra, Queen Kṣemavatī aspires to be reborn as a man so that she may progress on her path to awakening. It may be jarring to some readers to hear the queen lamenting her womanhood, but this is not uncommon in Mahāyāna writings. In her book Women in Buddhism, Diana Paul identifies three ways that Mahāyāna sūtras deal with the question of female awakening: some deny the possibility of awakening for women, some describe a lesser type of awakening for women, and some grant women the potential for full awakening.Paul 1979, p. 169 With its assertion that Queen Kṣemavatī must be reborn as a man in order to continue her spiritual development, The Prophecy of Kṣemavatī fits into this first category. Despite this assertion of the inadequacy of the female form, the sūtra is framed as an inspiration to women, as it ends with many thousands of women developing the intent to reach buddhahood.

While the text does not include a colophon that identifies its translators, we have some information about its history. The Prophecy of Kṣemavatī is listed in the earliest Tibetan textual catalog, the Denkarma, so we can say with certainty that it appeared in Tibet at some point during or before the early ninth century ce. See Denkarma, folio 299.b and Herrmann-Pfandt, p. 119. Despite this early arrival, it does not appear that The Prophecy of Kṣemavatī was the subject of any scholarly attention in Tibet. It was translated into Chinese (Taishō 573, cha mo po di shou chi jing, 差摩婆帝授記經) in the year 525 ce by the Indian monk Bodhiruci, who translated some thirty-nine Buddhist texts in the early sixth century. The Prophecy of Kṣemavatī was translated into Mongolian and Korean and is included in the Buddhist canons in those languages. This text was also translated into French in 1866 by Henri Léon Feer as part of his collection of Kangyur excerpts, and by Peter Skilling in 2021.

The English translation presented here was prepared based on the Degé (sde dge) Kangyur version of the text in consultation with the Stok Palace manuscript and the Pedurma (dpe bsdur ma) comparative edition.
Homage to all buddhas and bodhisattvas.

Thus did I hear at one time. The Blessed One was residing in Rājagṛha on Vulture Peak Mountain together with a large monastic congregation of twenty thousand monks and many bodhisattva great beings including Maitreya and Mañjuśrī. At dawn, the Blessed One donned his robes, picked up his alms bowl, and, together with the bodhisattva great being Maitreya, went to the city of Rājagṛha for alms. As they progressed through their rounds in the city of Rājagṛha, they neared the palace of King Bimbisāra. From atop the royal residence, King Bimbisāra’s queen, Kṣemavatī, could see the Blessed One approaching from a distance. Filled with joy at the sight of the Blessed One, Kṣemavatī descended from the palace and laid out ornate cushions made of white silk for the Blessed One and the bodhisattva great being Maitreya. The Blessed One and the bodhisattva great being Maitreya seated themselves on the seats that had been prepared for them, and Kṣemavatī, bedecked in all her jewelry, bowed her head to their feet. So that she might hear teachings on the Dharma, she sat before the Blessed One with great respect and reverence for him.

The Blessed One saw Queen Kṣemavatī bedecked in all her jewelry and, although he knew the answer, addressed her in order to benefit all beings. He asked, “Kṣemavatī, what is the name of the tree that bears the kind of brilliant, dazzling, shining fruit that adorns your body?”
Queen Kṣemavatī answered the Blessed One with the following verses:

lg.l: “The great being has asked,
‘What is the name of the tree
That bears the fruit you wear?’
Even though, great hero, you already know.
“It is called the tree arisen from the merit
Generated in the past.
Guide, these fruits I now enjoy
Are from a tree such as that.
“This very same fruit tree
Belongs to disciples of the Buddha.
Those who wish to obtain the wisdom of a Buddha
Sit before it in order to awaken.
“Watered with generosity and discipline,
This fruit tree has been well tended.
And when it fully blossoms,
It will bear sublime fruits.
“With the powers of patience and diligence,
I have carefully tended this fruit tree,
And when it blossoms,
It will bear flawless fruits.
“This tree is beautiful to behold,
Covered with flowers of concentration and insight.
Guide, all that I enjoy
Is the fruit of that tree.
“Just like trees
Rooted in the mountains
With outstretched limbs and leaves,
They spread far and wide without moving.
“In that way I carefully tended
This excellent broad fruit tree in the past
By seeking the essence of buddhahood
With the aim of benefitting all beings.
“Guide, Reading ’dren pa from KY, J, K,C, H, S in place of ’dren pa’i. this tree of merit
Will have many more fruits besides.
I will experience more
Than the mere flowers.
“I will attain the fruits of that tree—
Supreme awakening,
The unsurpassed awakening of a buddha.
When I leave this lowly station of womanhood behind,
“I will be reborn as a man
Who is sublime among all beings,
Has perfected all qualities,
And is all-knowing and all-seeing.
“I will liberate those beings
Who are oppressed by suffering,
And become a compassionate refuge
For the denizens of the world.”

div.p: The Blessed One responded, “Kṣemavatī, you have acted to bring benefit and happiness to many people and have compassion for the world. You have acted for the sake of the vast assembly of beings, for the happiness and benefit of gods and humans alike. Excellent, excellent indeed!”

“Blessed One,” Queen Kṣemavatī replied, “the Blessed One has the thirty-two major and eighty minor bodily marks of a great being, the ten powers of the thus-gone ones, the four fearlessnesses, four special modes of knowledge, the eighteen unique qualities of a buddha, great loving-kindness, great compassion, great joy, and great equanimity. Where do all of your qualities come from? And, furthermore, where do the unfathomable, inconceivable, immeasurable, ineffable, incalculable teachings of the Buddha come from?”
The Blessed One answered Queen Kṣemavatī with these verses:

lg.l: “Desiring the wisdom of the buddhas
In order to benefit all beings,
I too, in the past, have done nothing
But carefully tend such a tree.
“I gathered generosity, discipline, patience,
And likewise diligence and concentration.
For a long time, I applied myself
To absorption and insight.
“Beings have biased minds,
Yet my mind is impartial
Without needing to be cultivated.
Thus I discovered buddhahood itself.
“With an impartial mind
That equalizes
Beauty and ugliness, friend and foe,
I grew the tree of merit.
“As a result, this broad tree
Gained many excellent qualities.
I attained the state of a universal monarch
And the level of Śakra.
“I surpassed the many-formed Maheśvara,
And even Brahmā himself.
I have realized the qualities
Of the inconceivable teachings of the Buddha.”

div.p: After hearing of the qualities of the Blessed One, Queen Kṣemavatī praised the Blessed One’s well-spoken teaching and rejoiced, offering these verses:

lg.l: “Just as the supreme human, the excellent one,
With his endless ocean of qualities,
Trained his conduct in the past,
So will I train.
“As you have perfected all qualities,
I train to emulate your qualities.
Abandoning the suffering of existence,
I too will become like that.
“I fully dedicate
All the generosity I cultivate
In all my subsequent lives
To the attainment of unparalleled wisdom.
“I fully dedicate
All the discipline I maintain
In this life and any other
To the attainment of the wisdom of the buddhas.
“I dedicate
All the patience, diligence, absorption,
Insight, and virtue I cultivate
To be of benefit to the Buddha’s teachings.
“All the virtuous deeds I accrue
Through body, speech, and mind
I dedicate to awakening,
For the sake of the wisdom and qualities of buddhas.
“May I leave this woman’s body behind
And take the supreme form of a man.
Upon attaining the body of a man,
May I become the most sublime of beings.
“Once that has come to pass, I will turn
The unsurpassed wheel of the well-gone ones.
I will free the masses of beings
Who are trapped in the prison of saṃsāra.”

div.p: The Blessed One then offered his approval to Queen Kṣemavatī with this verse:

lg.l: “Those words were well spoken,
Your mind is well disciplined,
And you have subdued Māra well!
You will awaken to perfect buddhahood!”

div.p: Queen Kṣemavatī was joyful, elated, and jubilant. Filled with joy and delight, she offered the Blessed One and the bodhisattva great being Maitreya plenty of food and drink until they were satisfied. After the Blessed One put away his bowl and washed his hands, he gave Queen Kṣemavatī extensive Dharma teachings, encouraged her to uphold them, inspired her, delighted her, and then made this prophecy:

“In the future, Kṣemavatī, many eons from now, you will become a thus-gone, worthy, perfected buddha, a teacher for gods and humans. You will be a blessed buddha known as Guṇaratnaśrī, and your buddha field will be supremely pure. It will be free of the suffering of descending to lower rebirths and the lower realms. It will be an abode of beautiful, pleasant, and supremely pure bodhisattvas. Such will be your buddha field.”
As this teaching was given, many thousands of laywomen developed the intent to reach unexcelled, perfect awakening. Thousands of beings and many gods and humans obtained the light of the Dharma.
When the Blessed One had finished speaking, Queen Kṣemavatī, her retinue, and the entire world with its gods, humans, asuras, and gandharvas, all rejoiced and praised what the Buddha had taught.
div.trailer: This concludes the noble Mahāyāna sūtra, “The Prophecy of Kṣemavatī.”

gloss.term: thirty-two major marks of a great being
skyes bu chen po’i mtshan sum cu rtsa gnyis
The thirty-two major signs of a buddha that manifest as specific physical attributes to indicate the perfection of the awakened state of buddhahood.
dpe byad bzang po brgyad cu
A set of eighty bodily characteristics borne by buddhas and universal emperors. They are considered “minor” in terms of being secondary to the thirty-two major marks of a great being.
ten powers of the thus-gone ones
de bzhin gshegs pa’i stobs bcu

A category of qualities that are distinctive of a thus-gone one. They are as follows: knowing what is possible and what is impossible; knowing the results of actions or the ripening of karma; knowing the various inclinations of sentient beings; knowing the various elements; knowing the supreme and lesser faculties of sentient beings; knowing the paths that lead to all destinations of rebirth; knowing the concentrations, liberations, absorptions, equilibriums, afflictions, purifications, and abidings; knowing previous lives; knowing the death and rebirth of sentient beings; and knowing the cessation of the defilements.

The four types of fearlessness possessed by buddhas: They have full confidence that (1) they are fully awakened, (2) they have removed all defilements, (3) they have taught about the obstacles to liberation, and (4) they have shown the path to liberation.
so so yang dag par rig pa bzhi

The four correct and unhindered discriminating knowledges of (1) the doctrine or Dharma, (2) meaning, (3) language, and (4) brilliance or eloquence. These are the essential means by which the buddhas impart their teachings.
eighteen unique qualities of a buddha
sangs rgyas kyi chos ma ’dres pa bco brgyad
Eighteen special features of a buddha’s behavior, realization, activity, and wisdom that are not shared by other beings.
Literally “wheel wielder,” denotes a powerful being who has control over vast regions.

A class of nonhuman beings who are engaged in a mythic war with the gods (deva) for possession of the nectar of immortality. In Buddhist cosmology, they inhabit the realm neighboring that of the gods, from which they observe the gods with intense jealousy.
A class of generally benevolent nonhuman beings who inhabit the sky and are most renowned as celestial musicians.
A bodhisattva destined to be the buddha of the next epoch.
A great bodhisattva. As one of the eight “close sons” of the Buddha, he is the embodiment of wisdom.
King of Magadha who lived at the time of the Buddha Śākyamuni.
The mother of Suvarṇottamaprabhāsā, who was married to King Bimbisāra.
Alternate name for Indra, the lord who rules the Heaven of the Thirty-Three.
An epithet for the god Śiva.
A high-ranking deity who presides over a divine world where other beings consider him the creator; he is also considered to be the lord of the Sahā world (our universe).
The name of a future buddha.
The capital of the ancient kingdom of Magadha.
Name of a mountain close to Rājagṛha. It is famous as the place where the Buddha is said to have taught the Prajñāpāramitā and other teachings.
